Lion Witch Wardrobe at Children s Theatre of Charlotte

Order Reprint of this Story March 09 2018 12 46 PM Actors usually know they’ve got a grip on audiences when they hear noise laughter in the right places involuntary responses of joy or anguish bursts of applause. With kids you measure success by silence. They rarely clap until the end; even then they may be responding to the urging of a teacher or a parent. If you hear nothing – especially the nothing that comes when they stop wriggling and giggling and start listening – you’re a hit. So the pin-drop quiet during a school performance of “The Lion The Witch and the Wardrobe” bodes well for Children’s Theatre of Charlotte. Youngsters needed to work their imaginations full-out for an hour to envision C.S. Lewis’ Narnia aided only by two actors and half a dozen significant props on Tim Parati’s unfussy set. They did so easily. The script by South African actress Le Clanché du Rand opens in a room with a hat rack a couple of trunks a hobbyhorse and the iconic wardrobe portal to a land outside human time. (Lewis wrote the book in the late 1940s in a Europe still recovering from Nazism; people sometimes think the Witch who turns her world to a winter where Christmas never comes represents Hitler.) CTC artistic director Adam Burke took the helm for this show and makes minimalism pay off. When the children pass through the wardrobe into Narnia for the first time David Fillmore’s lighting illuminates a backdrop with a few pine trees and wisps of falling snow. Characters change quickly and simply Peter becomes snivelly Edmund by donning glasses and rounding his shoulders while Lucy converts to the older Susan by shoving her hands in her pockets and dropping her voice. Sutton and Giles snap into characters quickly and smoothly so the young audience never gets lost. Things that may sound ridiculous in print don’t raise a laugh onstage. Narrator Peter embodies Aslan by adding resonance to his voice (with help from sound designer Jason Romney) and holding aloft a sofa pillow bearing the face of a lion. When the siblings re-enact a swordfight with umbrellas Romney adds metallic clangs to make the battle seem less like childish hijinks. Completists will fidget at du Rand’s condensation. It eliminates Professor Kirke and all the battles and gives short shrift to Susan who might have been cut entirely from this version without being missed. The death of Aslan inspires no pathos in a story told so swiftly He’s slain he’s resurrected we move along. Yet the author develops all of Lewis’ important themes The need for quarreling allies to unite in the face of a monstrous enemy the sacrifices necessary to defeat evil the presence of a power greater than humanity that can change the fate of the world. If you want to pack those ideas into a cheerful and uplifting tale that lasts only an hour – just about the length a young audience can observe respectfully – this is the way to go. ‘The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe’ WHEN Through April 15 mostly at 7 30 p.m. Friday 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. Saturday 2 and 4 p.m. Sunday.
